snippet: There are nearly 400 police departments where a predominantly white force serves in mostly minority towns, showing the difficulty, even where there is a will, in hiring more minorities.
abstract: Police departments across the country still struggle to hire and retain minority candidates, issue that has taken on new relevance since fatal shooting of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo; analysis of data from federal survey of police departments in 2007 finds that nearly 400 departments were substantially whiter than populations they served.

byline.contributor: Richard A. Oppel Jr., Susan Beachy and Archie Tse contributed reporting from New York.

lead_paragraph: There are nearly 400 police departments where a predominantly white force serves in mostly minority towns, showing the difficulty, even where there is a will, in hiring more minorities.

headline.main: Mostly White Forces in Mostly Black Towns: Police Struggle for Racial Diversity
headline.print_headline: Mostly White Forces in Mostly Black Towns: Police Struggle for Racial Diversity
